repnme.cdata!:
Sudan - National Emergency Transport
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the National Emergency
            Transport Rehabilitation Project (NETREP) for Sudan were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory; risk to
            development outcome was substantial; Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory and borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: the
            joint co-financing arrangement has been challenged by the
            slow flow of counterpart funding for payment certificates
            for works executed by contractors and consultants. The
            project initially sought to reestablish basic transports
            services in the areas that came out of a protracted civil
            war, through spot improvement and maintenance of the
            existing roads. Capacity of the implementing entities was
            weak and Technical Assistance (TA) was sought in critical
            areas. However, the institutions were reluctant to have TA.
            Proactive project management is necessary to respond to
            changing circumstances. The design of the NETREP was
            substantially modified during implementation to take into
            account the changing situation. NETREP was designed to
            address sectorial challenges in a single operation within a
            short period of time. Despite difficult situation in post
            conflict environment where many things are uncertain and
            risks to Project Development Objective (PDO) were high, the
            Bank's decision to quickly respond to the
            country's immediate challenges, and thus taking risks
            to help, is commendable.

repnme.cdata!:
Sudan - National Emergency Transport
            Rehabilitation Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the National Emergency
            Transport Rehabilitation Project (NETRP) for Sudan is to
            facilitate the country's economic and social recovery
            through improved physical access to goods, markets, and
            administrative and social services. The changes involve: a)
            an extension of the project closing to complete the on-going
            road project which is stalled due to insecurity situation in
            the Blue Nile State; b) reallocation within and among
            components to: 1) avail funds to institutional development
            to continue with the capacity building activities; 2)
            provide additional funding to supervision services to cover
            the increased cost of supervision, during the extended
            period of roads contracts execution; and 3) allocate the
            balance of the Multi Donor Trust Fund for Sudan National
            Secretariat (MDTF-NS) allocation for the first section of
            the Damazin-Kurmuk road to the second section of the
            Damazin- Kurmuk road contract to cover additional financing
            requirements due to the insecurity, increase in quantities
            of existing bill items and escalation of prices; c) drop
            activities that will not be implemented under the NETRP; and
            d) revision of targets to reflect the changes. The closing
            date of the project will be extended to June 30, 2013, to
            allow the completion of ongoing contracts.

repnme.cdata!:
Sudan - National Emergency Transport
            Rehabilitation Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the National Emergency
            Transport Rehabilitation Project for Sudan is to facilitate
            the country's economic and social recovery through
            improved physical access to goods, markets, and
            administrative and social services. The changes involve: (i)
            reallocation within and among components to: (a) avail funds
            to institutional development to continue with the capacity
            building activities; (b) provide additional funding to
            supervision services to cover the increased cost of
            supervision, during the extended period of roads contracts
            execution; and (c) utilize the savings from low bid amounts
            to augment the financial provision to the ongoing road
            contracts to cover additional financing (AF) requirements
            due to increase in quantities of existing bill items; (ii)
            dropping activities that would not be implemented under the
            National Emergency Transport Rehabilitation Project
            (NETREP); and (iii) reflecting in project documents the
            cancellation of the allocation for lots A, C, D, and E of
            Kadugli - Kaouda road due to mis-procurement, and (iv)
            extension of the grant closing date by 12 months, from June
            30, 2011 to June 30, 2012, to allow the completion of
            ongoing contracts.
